trans-unit.source: How to use SQL Azure (Java) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use SQL Azure (Java) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use the Azure SQL Database from Java code.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use the Azure SQL Database from Java code.

trans-unit.source: How to Use Azure SQL Database in Java
trans-unit.target: How to Use Azure SQL Database in Java

trans-unit.source: The following steps show you how to use Azure SQL Database with Java.
trans-unit.target: The following steps show you how to use Azure SQL Database with Java.

trans-unit.source: Command line examples are shown for simplicity, but highly similar steps would be appropriate for web applications, either hosted on-premise, within Azure, or in other environments.
trans-unit.target: Command line examples are shown for simplicity, but highly similar steps would be appropriate for web applications, either hosted on-premise, within Azure, or in other environments.

trans-unit.source: This guide covers creating a server and creating a database from the <link><linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: This guide covers creating a server and creating a database from the <link><linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: What is Azure SQL Database
trans-unit.target: What is Azure SQL Database

trans-unit.source: Azure SQL Database provides a relational database management system for Azure, and is based on SQL Server technology.
trans-unit.target: Azure SQL Database provides a relational database management system for Azure, and is based on SQL Server technology.

trans-unit.source: With a SQL Database instance, you can easily provision and deploy relational database solutions to the cloud, and take advantage of a distributed data center that provides enterprise-class availability, scalability, and security with the benefits of built-in data protection and self-healing.
trans-unit.target: With a SQL Database instance, you can easily provision and deploy relational database solutions to the cloud, and take advantage of a distributed data center that provides enterprise-class availability, scalability, and security with the benefits of built-in data protection and self-healing.

trans-unit.source: Concepts
trans-unit.target: Concepts

trans-unit.source: Because Azure SQL Database is built on SQL Server technologies, accessing SQL Database from Java is very similar to accessing SQL Server from Java.
trans-unit.target: Because Azure SQL Database is built on SQL Server technologies, accessing SQL Database from Java is very similar to accessing SQL Server from Java.

trans-unit.source: You can develop an application locally (using SQL Server) and then connect to SQL Database by changing only the connection string.
trans-unit.target: You can develop an application locally (using SQL Server) and then connect to SQL Database by changing only the connection string.

trans-unit.source: You can use a SQL Server JDBC driver for your application.
trans-unit.target: You can use a SQL Server JDBC driver for your application.

trans-unit.source: However, there are some differences between SQL Database and SQL Server that could affect your application.
trans-unit.target: However, there are some differences between SQL Database and SQL Server that could affect your application.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Guidelines and Limitations (SQL Database)</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Guidelines and Limitations (SQL Database)</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: For additional resources for SQL Database, see the <link><linkText>Next steps[]</linkText><title></title></link> section.
trans-unit.target: For additional resources for SQL Database, see the <link><linkText>Next steps[]</linkText><title></title></link> section.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: The following are prerequisites if you intend to use SQL Database with Java.
trans-unit.target: The following are prerequisites if you intend to use SQL Database with Java.

trans-unit.source: A Java Developer Kit (JDK), v 1.6 or later.
trans-unit.target: A Java Developer Kit (JDK), v 1.6 or later.

trans-unit.source: An Azure subscription, which can be acquired from <html></html>.
trans-unit.target: An Azure subscription, which can be acquired from <html></html>.

trans-unit.source: If you are using Eclipse, you'll need Eclipse IDE for Java EE Developers, Indigo or later. This can be downloaded from <html></html>. You will also need the Azure Plugin for Eclipse with Java (by Microsoft Open Technologies). During installation of this plugin, ensure that Microsoft JDBC Driver 4.0 for SQL Server is included. For more information, see <link><linkText>Installing the Azure Plugin for Eclipse with Java (by Microsoft Open Technologies)</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you are using Eclipse, you'll need Eclipse IDE for Java EE Developers, Indigo or later. This can be downloaded from <html></html>. You will also need the Azure Plugin for Eclipse with Java (by Microsoft Open Technologies). During installation of this plugin, ensure that Microsoft JDBC Driver 4.0 for SQL Server is included. For more information, see <link><linkText>Installing the Azure Plugin for Eclipse with Java (by Microsoft Open Technologies)</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If you are not using Eclipse, you will need the Microsoft JDBC Driver 4.0 for SQL Server, which you can download from <html></html>.
trans-unit.target: If you are not using Eclipse, you will need the Microsoft JDBC Driver 4.0 for SQL Server, which you can download from <html></html>.

trans-unit.source: Creating an Azure SQL Database
trans-unit.target: Creating an Azure SQL Database

trans-unit.source: Before using Azure SQL Database in Java code, you will need to create an Azure SQL Database server.
trans-unit.target: Before using Azure SQL Database in Java code, you will need to create an Azure SQL Database server.

trans-unit.source: Login to the <link><linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Login to the <link><linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Click New.
trans-unit.target: Click New.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create new SQL database</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create new SQL database</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click SQL database, and then click Custom create.
trans-unit.target: Click SQL database, and then click Custom create.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create custom SQL database</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create custom SQL database</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Database settings dialog, specify your database name.
trans-unit.target: In the Database settings dialog, specify your database name.

trans-unit.source: For purposes of this guide, use gettingstarted as the database name.
trans-unit.target: For purposes of this guide, use gettingstarted as the database name.

trans-unit.source: For Server, select New SQL Database Server.
trans-unit.target: For Server, select New SQL Database Server.

trans-unit.source: Use the default values for the other fields.
trans-unit.target: Use the default values for the other fields.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>SQL database settings</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>SQL database settings</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click the next arrow.
trans-unit.target: Click the next arrow.

trans-unit.source: In the Server settings dialog, specify a SQL Server login name.
trans-unit.target: In the Server settings dialog, specify a SQL Server login name.

trans-unit.source: For purposes of this guide, MySQLAdmin was used.
trans-unit.target: For purposes of this guide, MySQLAdmin was used.

trans-unit.source: Specify and confirm a password.
trans-unit.target: Specify and confirm a password.

trans-unit.source: Specify a region, and ensure that Allow Azure Services to access the server is checked.
trans-unit.target: Specify a region, and ensure that Allow Azure Services to access the server is checked.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>SQL server settings</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>SQL server settings</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click the completion button.
trans-unit.target: Click the completion button.

trans-unit.source: Determining the SQL Database connection string
trans-unit.target: Determining the SQL Database connection string

trans-unit.source: Login to the <link><linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Login to the <link><linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Click SQL Databases.
trans-unit.target: Click SQL Databases.

trans-unit.source: Click the database that you want to use.
trans-unit.target: Click the database that you want to use.

trans-unit.source: Click Show connection strings.
trans-unit.target: Click Show connection strings.

trans-unit.source: Highlight the contents for the JDBC connection string.
trans-unit.target: Highlight the contents for the JDBC connection string.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Determine JDBC connection string</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Determine JDBC connection string</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Right-click the highlighted contents of the JDBC connection string and click Copy.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the highlighted contents of the JDBC connection string and click Copy.

trans-unit.source: You can now paste this value into your code file to create a connection string of the following form.
trans-unit.target: You can now paste this value into your code file to create a connection string of the following form.

trans-unit.source: Replace your_server (in two places) with the text you copied in the previous step, and replace your_password with the password value you specified when you created your SQL Database account.
trans-unit.target: Replace your_server (in two places) with the text you copied in the previous step, and replace your_password with the password value you specified when you created your SQL Database account.

trans-unit.source: (Also replace the values assigned to database= and user= if you did not use gettingstarted and MySQLAdmin, respectively.)
trans-unit.target: (Also replace the values assigned to database= and user= if you did not use gettingstarted and MySQLAdmin, respectively.)

trans-unit.source: String connectionString =
trans-unit.target: String connectionString =

trans-unit.source: "jdbc:sqlserver://your_server.database.windows.net:1433" + ";" +
trans-unit.target: "jdbc:sqlserver://your_server.database.windows.net:1433" + ";" +

trans-unit.source: "database=gettingstarted" + ";" +
trans-unit.target: "database=gettingstarted" + ";" +

trans-unit.source: "user=MySQLAdmin@your_server" + ";" +
trans-unit.target: "user=MySQLAdmin@your_server" + ";" +

trans-unit.source: "password=your_password" + ";" +
trans-unit.target: "password=your_password" + ";" +

trans-unit.source: "encrypt=true" + ";" +
trans-unit.target: "encrypt=true" + ";" +

trans-unit.source: "hostNameInCertificate=*.int.mscds.com" + ";" +
trans-unit.target: "hostNameInCertificate=*.int.mscds.com" + ";" +

trans-unit.source: "loginTimeout=30";
trans-unit.target: "loginTimeout=30";

trans-unit.source: We'll actually use this string later in this guide, for now you know the steps to determine the connection string.
trans-unit.target: We'll actually use this string later in this guide, for now you know the steps to determine the connection string.

trans-unit.source: Also, depending on your application needs, you may not need to use the encrypt and hostNameInCertificate settings, and you may need to modify the loginTimeout setting.
trans-unit.target: Also, depending on your application needs, you may not need to use the encrypt and hostNameInCertificate settings, and you may need to modify the loginTimeout setting.

trans-unit.source: To allow access to a range of IP addresses
trans-unit.target: To allow access to a range of IP addresses

trans-unit.source: Login to the <link><linkText>Management Portal</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Login to the <link><linkText>Management Portal</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Click SQL Databases.
trans-unit.target: Click SQL Databases.

trans-unit.source: Click Servers.
trans-unit.target: Click Servers.

trans-unit.source: Click the server that you want to use.
trans-unit.target: Click the server that you want to use.

trans-unit.source: Click Manage.
trans-unit.target: Click Manage.

trans-unit.source: Click Configure.
trans-unit.target: Click Configure.

trans-unit.source: Under Allowed IP addresses, enter the name of a new IP rule.
trans-unit.target: Under Allowed IP addresses, enter the name of a new IP rule.

trans-unit.source: Specify the beginning and ending range of the IP addresses.
trans-unit.target: Specify the beginning and ending range of the IP addresses.

trans-unit.source: For your convenience, the current client IP address is shown.
trans-unit.target: For your convenience, the current client IP address is shown.

trans-unit.source: The following example allows in a single client IP address (your IP address will be different).
trans-unit.target: The following example allows in a single client IP address (your IP address will be different).

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Allowed IP addresses dialog</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Allowed IP addresses dialog</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click the completion button.
trans-unit.target: Click the completion button.

trans-unit.source: The IP addresses that you specify will now be allowed access to your database server.
trans-unit.target: The IP addresses that you specify will now be allowed access to your database server.

trans-unit.source: To use Azure SQL Database in Java
trans-unit.target: To use Azure SQL Database in Java

trans-unit.source: Create a Java project.
trans-unit.target: Create a Java project.

trans-unit.source: For purposes of this tutorial, call it HelloSQLAzure.
trans-unit.target: For purposes of this tutorial, call it HelloSQLAzure.

trans-unit.source: Add a Java class file named HelloSQLAzure.java to the project.
trans-unit.target: Add a Java class file named HelloSQLAzure.java to the project.

trans-unit.source: Add the Microsoft JDBC Driver for SQL Server to your build path.
trans-unit.target: Add the Microsoft JDBC Driver for SQL Server to your build path.

trans-unit.source: If you are using Eclipse:
trans-unit.target: If you are using Eclipse:

trans-unit.source: Within Eclipse's Project Explorer, right-click the HelloSQLAzure project and click Properties.
trans-unit.target: Within Eclipse's Project Explorer, right-click the HelloSQLAzure project and click Properties.

trans-unit.source: In the left-hand pane of the Properties dialog, click Java Build Path.
trans-unit.target: In the left-hand pane of the Properties dialog, click Java Build Path.

trans-unit.source: Click the Libraries tab, and then click Add Library.
trans-unit.target: Click the Libraries tab, and then click Add Library.

trans-unit.source: In the Add Library dialog, select Microsoft JDBC Driver 4.0 for SQL Server, click Next, and then click Finish.
trans-unit.target: In the Add Library dialog, select Microsoft JDBC Driver 4.0 for SQL Server, click Next, and then click Finish.

trans-unit.source: Click OK to close the Properties dialog.
trans-unit.target: Click OK to close the Properties dialog.

trans-unit.source: If you are not using Eclipse, add the Microsoft JDBC Driver 4.0 for SQL Server JAR to your class path.
trans-unit.target: If you are not using Eclipse, add the Microsoft JDBC Driver 4.0 for SQL Server JAR to your class path.

trans-unit.source: For related information, see <link><linkText>Using the JDBC Driver</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For related information, see <link><linkText>Using the JDBC Driver</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Within your HelloSQLAzure.java code, add in import statements as shown in the following:
trans-unit.target: Within your HelloSQLAzure.java code, add in import statements as shown in the following:

trans-unit.source: Specify your connection string.
trans-unit.target: Specify your connection string.

trans-unit.source: Following is an example.
trans-unit.target: Following is an example.

trans-unit.source: As above, replace your_server (in two places), your_user and your_password with the values appropriate for your SQL Database server.
trans-unit.target: As above, replace your_server (in two places), your_user and your_password with the values appropriate for your SQL Database server.

trans-unit.source: You're now ready to add in code that will communicate with your SQL Database server.
trans-unit.target: You're now ready to add in code that will communicate with your SQL Database server.

trans-unit.source: Communicating with Azure SQL Database from your code
trans-unit.target: Communicating with Azure SQL Database from your code

trans-unit.source: The remainder of this topic shows examples that do the following:
trans-unit.target: The remainder of this topic shows examples that do the following:

trans-unit.source: Connect to the SQL Database server.
trans-unit.target: Connect to the SQL Database server.

trans-unit.source: Define a SQL statement, for example, to create or drop a table, insert/select/delete rows, etc.
trans-unit.target: Define a SQL statement, for example, to create or drop a table, insert/select/delete rows, etc.

trans-unit.source: Execute the SQL statement, either through a call to executeUpdate or executeQuery.
trans-unit.target: Execute the SQL statement, either through a call to executeUpdate or executeQuery.

trans-unit.source: Display query results, if appropriate.
trans-unit.target: Display query results, if appropriate.

trans-unit.source: The following sections are intended to be read (sampled) in order.
trans-unit.target: The following sections are intended to be read (sampled) in order.

trans-unit.source: The first snippet is a complete sample; the others would rely on part of the framework in the complete sample, such as the import statements, class and main declarations, error handling and resource closing.
trans-unit.target: The first snippet is a complete sample; the others would rely on part of the framework in the complete sample, such as the import statements, class and main declarations, error handling and resource closing.

trans-unit.source: Using SQL Database in Java within an Azure Deployment
trans-unit.target: Using SQL Database in Java within an Azure Deployment

trans-unit.source: To use SQL Database in Java within an Azure deployment, in addition to having Microsoft JDBC Driver 4.0 for SQL Server as a library in your class path as shown above, you'll need to package it with your deployment.
trans-unit.target: To use SQL Database in Java within an Azure deployment, in addition to having Microsoft JDBC Driver 4.0 for SQL Server as a library in your class path as shown above, you'll need to package it with your deployment.

trans-unit.source: Packaging the Microsoft JDBC Driver 4.0 SQL Server if you are using Eclipse
trans-unit.target: Packaging the Microsoft JDBC Driver 4.0 SQL Server if you are using Eclipse

trans-unit.source: Within Eclipse's Project Explorer, right-click your project and click Properties.
trans-unit.target: Within Eclipse's Project Explorer, right-click your project and click Properties.

trans-unit.source: In the left-hand pane of the Properties dialog, click Deployment Assembly, and then click Add.
trans-unit.target: In the left-hand pane of the Properties dialog, click Deployment Assembly, and then click Add.

trans-unit.source: In the New Assembly Directive dialog, click Java Build Path Entries and then click Next.
trans-unit.target: In the New Assembly Directive dialog, click Java Build Path Entries and then click Next.

trans-unit.source: Select Microsoft JDBC Driver 4.0 SQL Server and then click Finish.
trans-unit.target: Select Microsoft JDBC Driver 4.0 SQL Server and then click Finish.

trans-unit.source: Click OK to close the Properties dialog.
trans-unit.target: Click OK to close the Properties dialog.

trans-unit.source: Export your project's WAR file to your approot folder, and rebuild your Azure project, per the steps documented at <link><linkText>Creating a Hello World Application Using the Azure Plugin for Eclipse with Java (by Microsoft Open Technologies)</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Export your project's WAR file to your approot folder, and rebuild your Azure project, per the steps documented at <link><linkText>Creating a Hello World Application Using the Azure Plugin for Eclipse with Java (by Microsoft Open Technologies)</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: That topic also describes how to run your application in the compute emulator, and in Azure.
trans-unit.target: That topic also describes how to run your application in the compute emulator, and in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Packaging the Microsoft JDBC Driver 4.0 SQL Server if you are not using Eclipse
trans-unit.target: Packaging the Microsoft JDBC Driver 4.0 SQL Server if you are not using Eclipse

trans-unit.source: Ensure the Microsoft JDBC Driver 4.0 SQL Server library is included within the same Azure role as your Java application, and added to the class path of your application.
trans-unit.target: Ensure the Microsoft JDBC Driver 4.0 SQL Server library is included within the same Azure role as your Java application, and added to the class path of your application.

trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.target: To learn more about Microsoft JDBC Driver for SQL Server, see <link><linkText>Overview of the JDBC Driver</linkText><title></title></link>.
